ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Cells & stuff

I learned about the molecular and cellular bases of a variety of diseases.  We covered nearly every organ system in the body by the end of the semester -- not only how they function normally, but also how these processes may be disrupted.

Molecular machines, channels, pores, junctions, diseases. Hey when you take this course, focus on the biology, the mutations, treatments, tests. You can ignore the symptoms, calculations, and other medical jargon
I learned a lot about physiology and a lot about clinical disease cases.
I learned the biophysiological aspects of multiple diseases.
This class teaches a multitude of pathways and it is all in the context of diseases. The class requires learning how different pathways work and also reading papers and figures.
The different channels in our body and how they can contribute to some diseases.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: GOoD CoUrSE

Dr. Boulpaep's teaching philosophy was a MAJOR strength of this course.  His enthusiasm for the material made classes incredibly engaging, and I appreciated that he prioritizes understanding over memorizing.  Opening each lecture with a clinical case study made us engage in critical thinking and I liked how he used this as a framework for understanding how human physiology functions.  The lecture slides are dense with information and very meticulously put together.  It's evident that Dr. Boulpaep put a lot of thought and effort into the way he structures his classes and presentations.
Would have been helpful to have pictures of teh disease presentations to better contextualize what we are learning
By presenting each disease in the context of a clinical case, I was more engaged.
I loved the course. Professor Boulpaep is a course strength!

The course should change class time because it is hard to grasp the material early in the morning in a dry lecture. The class itself makes it hard to know what to focus on because the slides are so dense. Also, the font colors on the slides make it hard to see, so altering those may help. The pathways and diseases covered make sense and are important, but maybe more introduction to general physiology would be helpful.
The contents are good, its easy to follow after the whole background was built up, but for each single lecture, the slides are the way too more for only 50 minutes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! its with Emile boulpaep!
Absolutely!  This was by far one of the best STEM classes I've taken at Yale.  It was incredibly engaging and applicable, especially for those hoping to pursue a career in research and/or medicine.

yes, take it but keep in mind the material is tough. If you follow along with teh lectures and have a good understanding of everything, you'll be fine for the exam. The exams are easier than you think ;)
I would recommend this course to another student looking to learn more about physiology.
Sure! It seems good for people going to medical school. I do think there are better MCDB electives out there, though.
I will recommend this course as a audit course.  The exam is not that easy and closed book, you have to memorize a lot of things to do well in the exam. But over all, its an interesting course.
